Answer: I'm not really sure if there is a systematic approach to this (probably is, but I just don't know of it!)You really need to look at the innovators in the field and how much money is being invested into it.Good sources to find them are universities.What type of research is being funded more?This could be a good indicator as to what may be the next big thing.Personally I think it'll be 'smart foods' - products like Solyent will be more and more desired.

Answer: Sweet hairy hell yes. I am stunned by the ineptitude of people's knowledge about even basic first aid.I am also stunned that for a supposedly advanced country, so few people are taught how to do it from a young age. Especially CPR. It saves lives. End of. If children were taught it from a young age and given a basic exam in first aid management (basic dressings, CPR, bleeding management, choking etc). Nothing strenuous. Nothing too complicated, just enough to give people confidence in managing it. I have little doubt lives would be saved and we would get called to less rubbish.I recently was cSweet hairy hell yes. I am stunned by the ineptitude of people's knowledge about even basic first aid.I am also stunned that for a supposedly advanced country, so few people are taught how to do it from a young age. Especially CPR. It saves lives. End of. If children were taught it from a young age and given a basic exam in first aid management (basic dressings, CPR, bleeding management, choking etc). Nothing strenuous. Nothing too complicated, just enough to give people confidence in managing it. I have little doubt lives would be saved and we would get called to less rubbish.I recently was called because someone had a very minor burn. His wife had an amazing first aid kit….sealed…..she had bought it but had no idea how to use any of it. She had no idea what to do. This is so common it's frightening.

But in other fields, especially the machinery, German companies still have the lead. But I get your point. It might be due to military, since most technologic investments are first done for military purposes then come to civilian life, and Europe is pretty much a demilitarized zone compared to how it was 70 years ago. No European country actually bears a functioning, good funded and working military. Britain might be an exception but it is too struggling to keIf you mean the smartphones as emerging technologies, yes American and Korean/Japanese companies have pretty much own the whole market. But in other fields, especially the machinery, German companies still have the lead. But I get your point. It might be due to military, since most technologic investments are first done for military purposes then come to civilian life, and Europe is pretty much a demilitarized zone compared to how it was 70 years ago. No European country actually bears a functioning, good funded and working military. Britain might be an exception but it is too struggling to keep the small one it has, budget cuts all the time. Another explanations would be the aging population, increasing socialism which leads to mass laziness and death of creativity, rather stuffy and conservative views on new technologies from many European industrialists, and USA and Japan(later Korea and Taiwan) seizing the whole industry before anything is left to Europe.

Look at the world first in Germany and France by Airbus charging the aerospace industry. Airbus flew this year the 1st electric aircraft across the channel (E-Fan very exciting).
